thread.section_title: Australian Business & World Finance News - Yahoo!7 Finance
thread.title: $A dips on Chinese sharemarket pain

title: $A dips on Chinese sharemarket pain
text:
$A dips on Chinese sharemarket pain AAP â€“ 7 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar has slumped following renewed instability on Chinese stockmarkets. 
At 1700 AEST on Tuesday, the currency was trading at 73.47 US cents, down from 73.77 cents on Monday. 
National Australia Bank senior currency strategist Emma Lawson said the Aussie was underperforming against most major currencies. 
"That's likely a result of weakness in China's equity market," she said. 
After a relatively calm few weeks for China's volatile sharemarket, the Shanghai Composite suddenly fell 4.6 per cent in late trading. 
"China released its house price data this morning and that was a little better than expected," she said. 
Ms Lawson said there's now a slight concern China's central bank won't ease policy as expected, which is weighing on various upper assets. 
NAB on Monday revised its Aussie dollar forecasts lower, predicting a low of around 68 US cents in the first half of 2016 before a modest recovery back to or above 70 US cents by early 2017. 
Ms Lawson said additional commodity price falls and worries about emerging Asian markets contributed to their revision. 
"We (also) believe the market is yet to fully price in expectations for a (US) Fed rate hike, and therefore we're expecting more yield compression over time" she said. 
CURRENCY SNAPSHOT AT 1700 AEST ON TUESDAY 
One Australian dollar buys: 
* 73.47 US cents, from 73.77 cents on Monday 
* 91.37 Japanese yen, from 91.77 yen 
* 66.35 euro cents, from 66.47 euro cents 
* 111.57 New Zealand cents, from 112.58 NZ cents 
* 47.20 British pence, from 47.08 pence 
(*Currency closes taken at 1700 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
